ConceptDef.label: FD: Shield Generators
ConceptDef.helpText: Shields stop incoming projectiles at the cost of battery power. They don't stop people from moving through them, however. They use a low amount of power when idle and draw increased power when stopping incoming fire.\n\nIt is recommended to use batteries, as shields have a very high instant power draw. Automatic and sustained fire will drain power faster so multiple batteries are recommended.

ConceptDef.label: FD: Shield Coil Temperature
ConceptDef.helpText:
Shield coils heat up as the shield absorbs incoming projectiles. The generator will slowly exchange that heat with the room it's in until it reaches ambient temperature.

Over 100C: Minor failure, shield can cause shorts on the power network.

Over 150C: Moderate failure, shields can cause shorts and might breakdown.

 Over 200C: Critical failure, shield will short, breakdown, and suffer damage in an explosion.

ConceptDef.label: FD: Portable Shield Generators
ConceptDef.helpText: Portable Shields are miniaturizable emplacements which allow you to move the generator for your purposes. They come with a small internal battery which can power the unit as a standalone.\n\nIt can be connected to a normal power grid and will act as a normal battery. These shields have a fixed projection radius.
